title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others‚Äô private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement [conduct@tradingverse.org] opening issue. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired Mozilla‚Äôs code conduct enforcement ladder. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to tradeengine
text: Thank interest contributing tradeengine TradingVerse ecosystem! üöÄ

title: Contributing to tradeengine
text: project follows Code Conduct expect contributors adhere . Please respectful professional interactions.

title: Contributing to tradeengine
text: creating bug reports, please check existing issues. creating bug report, include: Clear title description Steps reproduce problem Expected vs actual behavior R version package versions Minimal reproducible example (reprex) Example:
code: library(tradeengine)  # Minimal code that reproduces the issue data <- market_tbl(...) # Error occurs here

title: Contributing to tradeengine
text: Enhancement suggestions tracked GitHub issues. Include: Clear title description enhancement Rationale: enhancement useful? Examples: work? Alternatives: considered approaches?

title: Contributing to tradeengine
text: Fork repository create branch main Write code following style guide (see ) Add tests new functionality Update documentation (roxygen2 comments vignettes) Run checks: devtools::check() pass errors Submit PR clear description

title: Contributing to tradeengine
code: # Install development dependencies install.packages(c("devtools", "testthat", "roxygen2", "pkgdown"))  # Clone repository # git clone https://github.com/Traderverse/tradeengine.git  # Load package for development devtools::load_all()  # Run tests devtools::test()  # Check package devtools::check()  # Build documentation devtools::document() pkgdown::build_site()

title: Contributing to tradeengine
text: follow tidyverse style guide: Key points: - Use snake_case function variable names - 2 spaces indentation (tabs) - Spaces around operators (x + y, x+y) - Use <- assignment, = - Maximum line length: 80 characters - Use explicit returns
code: # Good calculate_position_size <- function(capital, risk_percent) {   position <- capital * risk_percent   return(position) }  # Bad calc_pos_size<-function(x,y){ x*y }

title: Contributing to tradeengine
text: exported functions must roxygen2 documentation:
code: #' Calculate Position Size #' #' Calculates the position size based on capital and risk parameters. #' #' @param capital Numeric: available capital #' @param risk_percent Numeric: risk as percentage (e.g., 0.02 for 2%) #' @return Numeric: position size in dollars #' @export #' @examples #' calculate_position_size(10000, 0.02) calculate_position_size <- function(capital, risk_percent) {   position <- capital * risk_percent   return(position) }

title: Contributing to tradeengine
text: Every new function tests:
code: test_that("calculate_position_size works correctly", {   result <- calculate_position_size(10000, 0.02)   expect_equal(result, 200)      # Edge cases   expect_equal(calculate_position_size(0, 0.02), 0)   expect_error(calculate_position_size(-10000, 0.02)) })

title: Contributing to tradeengine
text: Standard Data Structure: Everything uses market_tbl Pipe-Friendly: Functions work |> %>% Minimal Dependencies: essential packages Extensible: Easy add new features Well-Documented: Clear examples vignettes

title: Contributing to tradeengine
text: adding features, consider: fit package scope? (backtesting simulation) generalizable? (works across asset classes) integrate well? (works existing functions) well-tested? (comprehensive test coverage)

title: Contributing to tradeengine
code: tradeengine/ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ R/ ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ market_tbl.R          # Data structure ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ strategy.R            # Strategy definition ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ backtest.R            # Backtesting engine ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ utils.R               # Utility functions ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ data.R                # Example data ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tests/ ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ testthat/ ‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ test-market_tbl.R ‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ test-strategy.R ‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ test-backtest.R ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ vignettes/ ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ getting-started.Rmd ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ examples/     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ basic_strategies.R

title: Pull Request
text: Fixes #(issue number)

title: Pull Request
text: Bug fix (non-breaking change fixes issue) New feature (non-breaking change adds functionality) Breaking change (fix feature cause existing functionality work expected) Documentation update Performance improvement Code refactoring Test improvements

title: Pull Request
text: tradeengine tradeio tradefeatures tradeviz tradedash trademetrics Documentation Infrastructure (GitHub Actions, etc.)

title: Pull Request
text: Change 1 Change 2 Change 3

title: Pull Request
code: # Example test code library(testthat) library(tradeengine)  test_that("new feature works", {   # Your test })

title: Pull Request
text: existing tests pass New tests added Manual testing completed

title: Pull Request
text: Current coverage: ___% Change coverage: +/- ___%

title: Pull Request
text: Function documentation (roxygen2) README updated (needed) Vignette updated/added (needed) NEWS.md updated Examples added/updated

title: Pull Request
text: Code follows tidyverse style guide R CMD check passes 0 errors, 0 warnings Function names descriptive consistent Comments clear helpful unnecessary dependencies added

title: Pull Request
code: # Old way: old_function(x)  # New way: new_function(x)

title: Pull Request
code: # Example output

title: Pull Request
text: read CONTRIBUTING guidelines code follows project style guide performed self-review code commented code, particularly hard--understand areas made corresponding changes documentation changes generate new warnings added tests prove fix effective feature works New existing unit tests pass locally changes dependent changes merged published

title: Pull Request
text: added examples updated relevant vignettes considered backward compatibility added appropriate error handling

title: Pull Request
text: added test caught bug verified fix original issue reporter (possible)

title: Pull Request
text: Update CHANGELOG Announce Discussions Update documentation site Notify users (breaking change) Thank contributing TradingVerse! üöÄ

title: ‚ö° TradingVerse Quick Start Guide
text: Welcome TradingVerse! guide get running tradeengine 5 minutes.

title: ‚ö° TradingVerse Quick Start Guide
code: # Install from GitHub (development version) devtools::install_github("tradingverse/tradeengine")  # Load package library(tradeengine) library(dplyr)

title: ‚ö° TradingVerse Quick Start Guide
code: # Generate synthetic data (or use tradeio to fetch real data) prices <- generate_synthetic_data(   n_days = 252,   start_price = 100,   volatility = 0.20,   symbol = "DEMO" )  # Take a look head(prices)

title: ‚ö° TradingVerse Quick Start Guide
code: # Calculate simple moving averages strategy_data <- prices |>   mutate(     sma_20 = sma(close, 20),  # Fast moving average     sma_50 = sma(close, 50)   # Slow moving average   )

title: ‚ö° TradingVerse Quick Start Guide
code: # Create a simple crossover strategy strategy <- strategy_data |>   add_strategy(     name = "SMA_Crossover",     entry_rules = sma_20 > sma_50,  # Buy when fast > slow     exit_rules = sma_20 < sma_50,   # Sell when fast < slow     position_size = 1000,            # $1000 per trade     commission = 0.001               # 0.1% commission   )

title: ‚ö° TradingVerse Quick Start Guide
code: # Execute the backtest results <- backtest(   strategy,   initial_capital = 10000,   method = "vectorized" )

title: ‚ö° TradingVerse Quick Start Guide
code: # Summary statistics summary(results)  # Plot equity curve plot(results)  # Check specific metrics results$total_return          # Total return percentage results$final_equity          # Ending capital results$n_trades              # Number of trades executed

title: ‚ö° TradingVerse Quick Start Guide
code: strategy <- prices |>   mutate(     sma = sma(close, 20),     distance = (close - sma) / sma   ) |>   add_strategy(     entry_rules = distance < -0.05,  # Buy 5% below mean     exit_rules = distance > 0,       # Sell at mean     position_size = 2000   )

title: ‚ö° TradingVerse Quick Start Guide
code: strategy <- prices |>   mutate(     returns_5d = (close / lag(close, 5) - 1),     sma_20 = sma(close, 20)   ) |>   add_strategy(     entry_rules = (returns_5d > 0.02) & (close > sma_20),     exit_rules = returns_5d < -0.01,     position_size = 1500   )

title: ‚ö° TradingVerse Quick Start Guide
code: strategy <- prices |>   mutate(     sma_20 = sma(close, 20),     roll_sd = sapply(seq_len(n()), function(i) {       if (i < 20) return(NA)       sd(close[max(1, i-19):i])     }),     upper = sma_20 + 2 * roll_sd,     lower = sma_20 - 2 * roll_sd   ) |>   add_strategy(     entry_rules = close > upper,  # Breakout above     exit_rules = close < sma_20,  # Exit at mean     position_size = 1000   )

title: ‚ö° TradingVerse Quick Start Guide
code: # Fixed amount calc_position_size("fixed", capital = 10000, price = 100, risk_per_trade = 0.02) # ‚Üí Risk 2% of capital  # Percentage of portfolio calc_position_size("percent_equity", capital = 10000, price = 100, risk_per_trade = 0.10) # ‚Üí Allocate 10% of portfolio  # Volatility targeting calc_position_size(   "volatility_target",   capital = 10000,   price = 100,   volatility = 0.30,   target_volatility = 0.10 ) # ‚Üí Target 10% portfolio volatility

title: ‚ö° TradingVerse Quick Start Guide
code: # Create a portfolio portfolio <- create_portfolio(   symbols = c("STOCK_A", "STOCK_B", "BOND_A"),   weights = c(0.4, 0.4, 0.2),   rebalance_frequency = "monthly",   initial_capital = 100000 )

title: ‚ö° TradingVerse Quick Start Guide
code: # Run backtest results <- backtest(strategy, initial_capital = 10000)  # Access results results$equity_curve          # Full equity curve data results$trades                # Individual trade details results$final_equity          # Ending equity results$total_return          # Overall return results$n_trades              # Number of trades  # Equity curve details head(results$equity_curve) # ‚Üí datetime, equity, cash, position, returns  # Trade details head(results$trades) # ‚Üí entry/exit dates, prices, PnL, commission

title: ‚ö° TradingVerse Quick Start Guide
code: # Requires ggplot2 library(ggplot2)  # Basic equity curve plot(results)  # Custom plots ggplot(results$equity_curve, aes(x = datetime, y = equity)) +   geom_line(color = "blue") +   labs(title = "Strategy Performance", y = "Equity ($)")  # Plot returns distribution ggplot(results$equity_curve, aes(x = returns)) +   geom_histogram(bins = 50, fill = "steelblue") +   labs(title = "Returns Distribution")

title: Security Policy
text: release patches security vulnerabilities following versions:

title: Security Policy
text: take security TradingVerse seriously. discover security vulnerability, please follow steps:

what: 1. Do Not Open a Public Issue
title: Security Policy
text: Please open public GitHub issue security vulnerabilities. helps prevent vulnerability exploited fix available.

title: Security Policy
text: Report security vulnerabilities via one methods: Email: security@tradingverse.org (preferred) GitHub Security Advisory: Use ‚ÄúReport vulnerability‚Äù button Security tab Direct Message: Contact maintainer directly

title: Security Policy
text: Please include: Description vulnerability Steps reproduce issue Potential impact suggested fixes (optional) contact information follow-

title: Security Policy
text: Acknowledgment: Within 48 hours Initial Assessment: Within 1 week Critical: Within 7 days High: Within 30 days Medium: Within 90 days Low: Next regular release

title: Security Policy
text: work understand resolve issue notify affected users fix available credit security advisory (unless prefer remain anonymous) follow responsible disclosure practices

title: Security Policy
text: TradingVerse primarily designed educational research purposes. using production trading environments: API Keys: Never commit API keys credentials repository Data Privacy: cautious sensitive trading data Financial Risk: Understand bugs result financial losses Testing: Thoroughly test strategies paper trading live deployment Compliance: Ensure compliance relevant financial regulations

title: Security Policy
text: Use environment variables sensitive data Regularly update dependencies Review code deploying production Use secure connections (HTTPS) data fetching Implement proper error handling logging Follow principle least privilege

title: Security Policy
text: Past security advisories published : https://github.com/Traderverse/tradingverse/security/advisories

title: Security Policy
text: questions security policy, please open discussion GitHub Discussions forum contact us security@tradingverse.org. Remember: open-source software provided ‚Äú‚Äù without warranty. Users responsible trading decisions risk management.

title: Getting Started with tradeengine
text: Welcome tradeengine, backtesting engine quantitative trading strategies R! vignette walk basics creating, testing, analyzing trading strategies using TradingVerse framework.

title: Getting Started with tradeengine
text: tradeengine follows tidyverse philosophy: Pipe-friendly: Use |> %>% chain operations Consistent API: Predictable function names parameters Tidy data: Everything works tibbles Flexible: simple complex strategies

title: Getting Started with tradeengine
code: # Install from GitHub devtools::install_github("tradingverse/tradeengine") library(tradeengine) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

title: Getting Started with tradeengine
text: tradeengine operations start market_tbl - standardized tibble financial time series data.

title: Getting Started with tradeengine
text: testing learning, tradeengine provides synthetic data generator:

title: Getting Started with tradeengine
text: Let‚Äôs build classic SMA crossover strategy:
code: # Add technical indicators strategy_data <- synthetic |>   mutate(     sma_20 = sma(close, 20),     sma_50 = sma(close, 50)   )  # Define strategy rules strategy <- strategy_data |>   add_strategy(     name = "SMA_Crossover",     entry_rules = sma_20 > sma_50,   # Buy when fast crosses above slow     exit_rules = sma_20 < sma_50,    # Sell when fast crosses below slow     position_size = 1000,             # $1000 per trade     commission = 0.001,               # 0.1% commission     slippage = 0.0005                 # 0.05% slippage   )  head(strategy, 10) #> # Market Data Tibble (market_tbl) #> # Frequency: daily  #> # Timezone: UTC  #> # Asset Class: equity  #> # Symbols: 1 unique #> # Observations: 10  #> # Date Range: 2024-01-02 to 2024-01-13  #>  #> # A tibble: 10 √ó 17 #>    symbol datetime             open  high   low close   volume adjusted sma_20 #>    <chr>  <dttm>              <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>  <dbl> #>  1 DEMO   2024-01-02 00:00:00  100   101.  99.5  100   415388.     100      NA #>  2 DEMO   2024-01-03 00:00:00  100.  102. 100.   102.  775402.     102.     NA #>  3 DEMO   2024-01-04 00:00:00  102.  102. 100.   101. 1270709.     101.     NA #>  4 DEMO   2024-01-05 00:00:00  101.  102. 101.   102.  914355.     102.     NA #>  5 DEMO   2024-01-06 00:00:00  102.  103. 102.   102.  918436.     102.     NA #>  6 DEMO   2024-01-09 00:00:00  103.  103. 102.   103. 1298040.     103.     NA #>  7 DEMO   2024-01-10 00:00:00  103.  104. 102.   103.  849331.     103.     NA #>  8 DEMO   2024-01-11 00:00:00  103.  105. 103.   105. 1207607.     105.     NA #>  9 DEMO   2024-01-12 00:00:00  105.  105. 104.   105.  652659.     105.     NA #> 10 DEMO   2024-01-13 00:00:00  105.  108. 105.   108.  691942.     108.     NA #> # ‚Ñπ 8 more variables: sma_50 <dbl>, entry_signal <lgl>, exit_signal <lgl>, #> #   strategy_name <chr>, position_size <dbl>, side <chr>, commission <dbl>, #> #   slippage <dbl>

title: Getting Started with tradeengine
text: fastest method signal-based strategies:
code: results <- backtest(   strategy,   initial_capital = 10000,   method = "vectorized" )  # View summary summary(results) #> === Backtest Results === #>  #> Configuration: #>   Initial Capital: $10,000 #>   Method: vectorized  #>   Commission: 0.1 % #>   Slippage: 0.05 % #>  #> Performance: #>   Final Equity: $9,940.222 #>   Total Return: -0.6 % #>   Number of Trades: 2  #>  #> Trade Summary: #>   Total Trades: 2

") #> Final Equity: $ 9,940.222 cat("Total Return: ", round(results$total_return * 100, 2), "%

title: Getting Started with tradeengine
text: tradeengine supports multiple position sizing approaches:
code: # Fixed dollar amount calc_position_size("fixed", capital = 10000, price = 100, risk_per_trade = 0.02) #> [1] 2  # Percentage of equity calc_position_size("percent_equity", capital = 10000, price = 100, risk_per_trade = 0.05) #> [1] 5  # Volatility targeting calc_position_size(   "volatility_target",    capital = 10000,    price = 100,   volatility = 0.30,        # Asset volatility   target_volatility = 0.10  # Target portfolio volatility ) #> [1] 33

title: Getting Started with tradeengine
text: Create backtest multi-asset portfolios:
code: # Create a 60/40 stock/bond portfolio portfolio <- create_portfolio(   symbols = c("SPY", "TLT"),   weights = c(0.6, 0.4),   rebalance_frequency = "monthly",   initial_capital = 100000 )  # Backtest portfolio portfolio_results <- backtest(portfolio)

title: Getting Started with tradeengine
text: can create sophisticated multi-condition strategies:
code: # Multi-indicator strategy complex_strategy <- synthetic |>   mutate(     sma_20 = sma(close, 20),     sma_50 = sma(close, 50),     returns = calc_returns_simple(close)   ) |>   add_strategy(     name = "Multi_Indicator",     entry_rules = (sma_20 > sma_50) & (returns > 0) & (volume > lag(volume)),     exit_rules = (sma_20 < sma_50) | (returns < -0.05),  # Exit or stop loss     position_size = 2000   )

title: Getting Started with tradeengine
text: Real trading costs. Always model :
code: strategy <- data |>   add_strategy(     entry_rules = ...,     exit_rules = ...,     commission = 0.001,  # 0.1% per trade     slippage = 0.0005    # 0.05% slippage   )

title: Getting Started with tradeengine
text: Don‚Äôt risk entire capital one trade:
code: # Risk 2% of capital per trade position_size_func <- function(equity, price) {   risk_amount <- equity * 0.02   shares <- risk_amount / price   return(floor(shares)) }

title: Getting Started with tradeengine
text: Always check market data:
code: # Check for issues validate_market_tbl(prices)  # Look for gaps summary(prices)

title: Getting Started with tradeengine
text: Begin simple strategies add complexity gradually: Single indicator (SMA) Two indicators (SMA crossover) Multiple conditions Position sizing rules Portfolio allocation

title: Getting Started with tradeengine
text: Strategy Design: Learn advanced strategy patterns Transaction Costs: Understand slippage market impact Portfolio Management: Multi-asset backtesting Walk-Forward Analysis: --sample testing

title: Getting Started with tradeengine
text: tradeengine part larger ecosystem:
code: library(tradeio)        # Data acquisition library(tradefeatures)  # Technical indicators   library(tradeviz)       # Visualization library(trademetrics)   # Performance analytics  # Complete workflow results <- fetch_prices("AAPL", from = "2023-01-01") |>  # tradeio   add_rsi(14) |>                                         # tradefeatures   add_strategy(entry = rsi < 30, exit = rsi > 70) |>    # tradeengine   backtest(initial_capital = 10000) |>                   # tradeengine   calc_sharpe() |>                                       # trademetrics   plot_equity_curve()                                    # tradeviz

title: tradeengine ‚Ä¢ Backtesting Engine for R
text: tradeengine powerful flexible backtesting engine quantitative trading strategies R. provides: üöÄ Vectorized & Event-Driven Backtesting - Choose approach fits strategy üíº Multi-Asset Support - Equities, crypto, futures, FX, üí∞ Realistic Cost Modeling - Commissions, slippage, market impact üìä Portfolio Management - Position sizing, rebalancing, risk controls üîÑ Walk-Forward Analysis - --sample testing üß© Pipe-Friendly - Works seamlessly tidyverse workflows

title: tradeengine ‚Ä¢ Backtesting Engine for R
code: # Install from GitHub (development version) # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("tradingverse/tradeengine")

title: tradeengine ‚Ä¢ Backtesting Engine for R
code: library(tradeengine) library(dplyr)  # Create market data (or use tradeio package to fetch) prices <- market_tbl(   symbol = rep("AAPL", 100),   datetime = seq.POSIXt(as.POSIXct("2024-01-01"), by = "day", length.out = 100),   open = rnorm(100, 150, 5),   high = rnorm(100, 152, 5),   low = rnorm(100, 148, 5),   close = rnorm(100, 150, 5),   volume = rnorm(100, 1e6, 1e5) )  # Define a simple moving average crossover strategy strategy <- prices |>   add_strategy(     name = "SMA_Crossover",     entry_rules = sma_short > sma_long,     exit_rules = sma_short < sma_long,     position_size = 1000,  # $1000 per trade     commission = 0.001      # 0.1% commission   )  # Run backtest results <- backtest(   data = strategy,   initial_capital = 10000,   method = "vectorized" )  # View summary summary(results)

title: tradeengine ‚Ä¢ Backtesting Engine for R
text: tradeengine functions work standardized market_tbl tibble:
code: data <- market_tbl(   symbol = c("AAPL", "AAPL"),   datetime = as.POSIXct(c("2024-01-01", "2024-01-02")),   open = c(150, 151),   high = c(152, 153),   low = c(149, 150),   close = c(151, 152),   volume = c(1e6, 1.1e6) )

title: tradeengine ‚Ä¢ Backtesting Engine for R
code: # Simple strategy strategy <- add_strategy(   data,   entry_rules = close > sma(close, 20),   exit_rules = close < sma(close, 20) )  # Complex multi-condition strategy strategy <- add_strategy(   data,   entry_rules = (rsi < 30) & (volume > volume_sma),   exit_rules = (rsi > 70) | (stop_loss_hit),   position_size_func = function(equity, price) {     risk_per_trade <- equity * 0.02     position_size <- risk_per_trade / (price * 0.05)     return(position_size)   } )

title: tradeengine ‚Ä¢ Backtesting Engine for R
code: results <- backtest(   data,   commission = 0.001,           # 0.1% per trade   slippage = 0.0005,           # 0.05% slippage   market_impact = function(volume, avg_volume) {     ifelse(volume > avg_volume * 0.01, 0.001, 0)   } )

title: tradeengine ‚Ä¢ Backtesting Engine for R
code: # Create multi-asset portfolio portfolio <- create_portfolio(   symbols = c("AAPL", "MSFT", "GOOGL"),   weights = c(0.4, 0.3, 0.3),   rebalance_frequency = "monthly" )  # Run portfolio backtest results <- backtest(   portfolio,   initial_capital = 100000,   rebalance = TRUE )

title: tradeengine ‚Ä¢ Backtesting Engine for R
text: Fast, ideal simple signal-based strategies:
code: results <- backtest(data, method = "vectorized")

title: tradeengine ‚Ä¢ Backtesting Engine for R
text: realistic, handles complex order logic:
code: results <- backtest(   data,    method = "event_driven",   order_types = c("market", "limit", "stop") )

title: tradeengine ‚Ä¢ Backtesting Engine for R
text: tradeengine designed work seamlessly TradingVerse packages:
code: library(tradeio)        # Data acquisition library(tradefeatures)  # Technical indicators library(tradeviz)       # Visualization library(trademetrics)   # Performance analytics  # Complete workflow results <- fetch_prices("AAPL", from = "2023-01-01") |>  # tradeio   add_sma(20) |>                                         # tradefeatures   add_rsi(14) |>                                         # tradefeatures   add_strategy(entry = rsi < 30, exit = rsi > 70) |>    # tradeengine   backtest(initial_capital = 10000) |>                   # tradeengine   calc_sharpe() |>                                       # trademetrics   plot_equity_curve()                                    # tradeviz

what: Add Trading Strategy to Market Data ‚Äî add_strategy
title: Add Trading Strategy to Market Data ‚Äî add_strategy
text: Adds trading strategy signals market_tbl object. function allows define entry exit rules, position sizing, strategy parameters.

title: Add Trading Strategy to Market Data ‚Äî add_strategy
code: add_strategy(   data,   name = "Strategy",   entry_rules,   exit_rules,   position_size = 1000,   side = "long",   stop_loss = NULL,   take_profit = NULL,   commission = 0.001,   slippage = 5e-04 )

title: Add Trading Strategy to Market Data ‚Äî add_strategy
text: data market_tbl object name Character string naming strategy (default: "Strategy") entry_rules Expression logical vector defining entry conditions exit_rules Expression logical vector defining exit conditions position_size Numeric value function position sizing side Character: "long", "short", "" (default: "long") stop_loss Numeric value stop loss percentage (e.g., 0.05 5%) take_profit Numeric value take profit percentage commission Numeric value commission rate (e.g., 0.001 0.1%) slippage Numeric value slippage rate

title: Add Trading Strategy to Market Data ‚Äî add_strategy
text: market_tbl object added strategy columns

title: Add Trading Strategy to Market Data ‚Äî add_strategy
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(tradeengine)  # Simple moving average crossover strategy <- prices |>   add_strategy(     name = "SMA_Cross",     entry_rules = sma_fast > sma_slow,     exit_rules = sma_fast < sma_slow,     position_size = 1000   ) } # }

title: Convert to Market Data Tibble ‚Äî as_market_tbl
code: # Convert a regular data frame df <- data.frame(   symbol = rep("AAPL", 3),   datetime = as.POSIXct(c("2024-01-01", "2024-01-02", "2024-01-03")),   open = c(150, 151, 152),   high = c(152, 153, 154),   low = c(149, 150, 151),   close = c(151, 152, 153),   volume = c(1e6, 1.1e6, 1.2e6) )  market_data <- as_market_tbl(df)

title: Run Strategy Backtest ‚Äî backtest
text: Executes complete backtest trading strategy market data. Supports vectorized (fast, signal-based) event-driven (realistic, order-based) backtesting methods.

title: Run Strategy Backtest ‚Äî backtest
code: backtest(   data,   initial_capital = 10000,   method = "vectorized",   commission = NULL,   slippage = NULL,   position_size_method = "fixed",   max_positions = 1,   margin_requirement = 1,   compound = TRUE )

title: Run Strategy Backtest ‚Äî backtest
text: data market_tbl object strategy signals (add_strategy()) initial_capital Numeric value starting capital method Character: "vectorized" "event_driven" commission Numeric: commission rate (overrides strategy commission provided) slippage Numeric: slippage rate (overrides strategy slippage provided) position_size_method Character: position sizing method max_positions Integer: maximum number concurrent positions (default: 1) margin_requirement Numeric: margin requirement fraction (default: 1, leverage) compound Boolean: whether compound returns (default: TRUE)

title: Run Strategy Backtest ‚Äî backtest
text: backtest_results object containing trades, equity curve, statistics

title: Run Strategy Backtest ‚Äî backtest
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(tradeengine)  # Run a simple backtest results <- prices |>   add_strategy(     entry_rules = close > sma_20,     exit_rules = close < sma_20   ) |>   backtest(initial_capital = 10000, method = "vectorized")  # View results summary(results) plot(results) } # }

title: Event-Driven Backtesting Engine ‚Äî backtest_event_driven

code: backtest_event_driven(   data,   initial_capital,   compound,   max_positions,   margin_requirement )

title: Event-Driven Backtesting Engine ‚Äî backtest_event_driven
text: data Market data strategy signals initial_capital Starting capital compound Whether compound returns max_positions Maximum concurrent positions margin_requirement Margin requirement fraction

title: Event-Driven Backtesting Engine ‚Äî backtest_event_driven
text: List trades equity curve

title: Vectorized Backtesting Engine ‚Äî backtest_vectorized

text: data Market data strategy signals initial_capital Starting capital compound Whether compound returns max_positions Maximum concurrent positions margin_requirement Margin requirement fraction

title: Calculate Position Size ‚Äî calc_position_size
text: method Character: "fixed", "percent_equity", "risk_parity", "volatility_target" capital Numeric value available capital price Numeric value asset price risk_per_trade Numeric: risk per trade fraction capital (risk-based methods) volatility Numeric: asset volatility (volatility-based methods) target_volatility Numeric: target portfolio volatility (default: 0.10) ... Additional parameters custom sizing methods

title: Calculate Position Size ‚Äî calc_position_size
text: Numeric value representing position size (number shares/units)

title: Calculate Position Size ‚Äî calc_position_size
code: # Fixed position size calc_position_size("fixed", capital = 10000, price = 100) #> [1] 2  # 2% of equity calc_position_size("percent_equity", capital = 10000, price = 100, risk_per_trade = 0.02) #> [1] 2  # Volatility-targeted calc_position_size("volatility_target", capital = 10000, price = 100,                     volatility = 0.20, target_volatility = 0.10) #> [1] 50

what: Create a Market Data Tibble ‚Äî market_tbl
title: Create a Market Data Tibble ‚Äî market_tbl
text: Creates standardized market data tibble (market_tbl) serves foundation tradeengine operations. core data structure used across entire TradingVerse ecosystem.

title: Create a Market Data Tibble ‚Äî market_tbl
code: market_tbl(   symbol,   datetime,   open,   high,   low,   close,   volume,   adjusted = NULL,   frequency = "daily",   timezone = "UTC",   asset_class = "equity" )

title: Create a Market Data Tibble ‚Äî market_tbl
text: symbol Character vector asset symbols/tickers datetime POSIXct vector timestamps (timezone-aware) open Numeric vector opening prices high Numeric vector high prices low Numeric vector low prices close Numeric vector closing prices volume Numeric vector trading volume adjusted Numeric vector adjusted closing prices (optional) frequency Character string indicating data frequency (e.g., "1min", "1hour", "daily") timezone Character string timezone (default: "UTC") asset_class Character string asset class (e.g., "equity", "crypto", "futures", "fx")

title: Create a Market Data Tibble ‚Äî market_tbl
text: market_tbl object (enhanced tibble) standardized market data

title: Create a Market Data Tibble ‚Äî market_tbl
code: # Create daily stock data prices <- market_tbl(   symbol = rep("AAPL", 5),   datetime = seq.POSIXt(as.POSIXct("2024-01-01"), by = "day", length.out = 5),   open = c(150, 151, 152, 151, 153),   high = c(152, 153, 154, 153, 155),   low = c(149, 150, 151, 150, 152),   close = c(151, 152, 153, 152, 154),   volume = c(1e6, 1.1e6, 1.2e6, 1.15e6, 1.3e6) )  # Create crypto data with 1-hour frequency btc <- market_tbl(   symbol = rep("BTC-USD", 24),   datetime = seq.POSIXt(as.POSIXct("2024-01-01"), by = "hour", length.out = 24),   open = rnorm(24, 50000, 500),   high = rnorm(24, 50500, 500),   low = rnorm(24, 49500, 500),   close = rnorm(24, 50000, 500),   volume = rnorm(24, 100, 10),   frequency = "1hour",   asset_class = "crypto" ) #> Warning: Inconsistent OHLC prices detected (high < low or similar)

title: Create Trading Session Object ‚Äî trading_session
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(tradeengine) library(tradeio) library(tradefeatures)  # Create session session <- trading_session(   data = fetch_yahoo("AAPL"),   name = "AAPL SMA Crossover",   description = "Testing 20/50 SMA crossover with RSI filter" )  # Add features session <- session %>%   add_features(     sma_20 = add_sma(20),     sma_50 = add_sma(50),     rsi = add_rsi(14)   )  # Add strategy session <- session %>%   add_strategy(     entry = sma_20 > sma_50 & rsi < 70,     exit = sma_20 < sma_50 | rsi > 80   )  # Run backtest session <- session %>%   run_backtest(initial_capital = 100000)  # See what you have print(session) summary(session)  # Visualize plot(session)  # Equity curve plot(session, type = "drawdown") plot(session, type = "returns")  # Launch dashboard dashboard(session) } # }
